input:
1. A 7-year-old male is referred to the audiology clinic after his teacher notices he frequently asks for repetition during class and seems withdrawn in group conversations. He passed his newborn hearing screening but gradually showed signs of hearing difficulty over the past two years, with no history of ear infections or head trauma. His parents report no exposure to loud noises or ototoxic drugs, and there is no known family history of hearing loss. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no craniofacial anomalies or vestibular dysfunction observed. Audiometric evaluation demonstrates moderate-to-severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, predominantly affecting high frequencies. Imaging studies, including MRI of the inner ear, reveal normal cochlear and auditory nerve anatomy. Genetic analysis identifies a homozygous pathogenic variant linked to autosomal recessive nonsyndromic neurosensory deafness. Management includes fitting with hearing amplification devices and enrollment in auditory-verbal therapy to support language acquisition and academic performance.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient is young, and probably confused about why they're here. They might be feeling a bit anxious, maybe worried about what the doctor will say. They probably can't give a very clear explanation but will share what they’re experiencing in simple, vague terms.

ANSWER: I’m not feeling like myself, I guess. I keep asking people to say it again, and I don’t really understand what they’re saying sometimes. It’s been happening for a while, and I don’t know why, but I just don’t hear things right.

input: 1. A 7-year-old male is referred to the audiology clinic after his teacher notices he frequently asks for repetition during class and seems withdrawn in group conversations. Genetic analysis identifies a homozygous pathogenic variant linked to autosomal recessive nonsyndromic neurosensory deafness. Management includes fitting with hearing amplification devices and enrollment in auditory-verbal therapy to support language acquisition and academic performance.Can you tell me more about how your difficulty understanding speech has changed over time—has it been sudden, gradual, or does it come and go? Are there any other symptoms you're experiencing along with this, like weakness, numbness, or headaches?
output: Um, I think it’s been kind of slow… like, I didn’t notice it all at once, but now it’s harder to understand sometimes, especially with lots of noise. I don’t really get headaches or anything, but sometimes I feel sort of tired or weird in my head, like it’s hard to focus.

input: 1. A 7-year-old male is referred to the audiology clinic after his teacher notices he frequently asks for repetition during class and seems withdrawn in group conversations. Audiometric evaluation demonstrates moderate-to-severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, predominantly affecting high frequencies. Imaging studies, including MRI of the inner ear, reveal normal cochlear and auditory nerve anatomy. Genetic analysis identifies a homozygous pathogenic variant linked to autosomal recessive nonsyndromic neurosensory deafness. Management includes fitting with hearing amplification devices and enrollment in auditory-verbal therapy to support language acquisition and academic performance.Can you describe how your symptoms affect your daily life—are there particular activities or environments where your trouble understanding speech becomes worse or better?
output: Um, I guess it's harder for me when there's a lot of noise around, like in the cafeteria or when there are lots of kids talking at once. Sometimes I can't catch what people are saying, even when they repeat. It makes me feel kind of shy and I don’t always answer right away because I’m not sure I got it.

output: I guess I sometimes miss what people say, especially if there's lots of noise or if they’re far away. It feels worse when everyone talks at once or when I go to loud places like the cafeteria. Sometimes, I think I hear okay, but then later I realize I didn’t catch what was said.

And have you experienced any dizziness, balance problems, or ear pain?
output: Um, I don’t think I hear anything weird, like buzzing or ringing. And I don’t really feel dizzy or anything, and my ears don’t hurt, I guess.

output: Umm, I don’t know, I guess sometimes I forget stuff more than before, like names or what we were talking about maybe. But I’m not sure if it’s just me not paying attention or if it’s something else.
